I so understand where you're coming from, because it[.] exactly the same logic I've used to justify going to grad school when everyone around me is saying it[.] not worth it, but - the situation in humanities academia is unlikely to make a drastic shift in the next 10 (or even 20) years, especially because current professors are clinging to their jobs longer and longer. It isn't just a matter of the recession or the current job market - securing jobs in academia (and particularly in humanities) has been getting more and more difficult for a long time. And keep in mind that "who knows" also means "who knows if it'll get much worse."

Just to clarify, I'm not saying YOU CAN'T DO IT!! because I'm sure you would be a great professor - and I'm not even saying YOU WON'T GET A CHANCE because maybe you will - I'm just saying it would be wise to have a backup option and to consider lots of career/field choices before you set your mind on doing the most difficult thing you can do with a humanities degree. That is: get a degree in a humanities field because it[.] what you want to learn about, not because you think it'll open the door to professorships - and make sure there are other options for you, either with that degree or with additional majors and minors.
